subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Design?
msgSnippet: Eric and Vladimir, ... Could you clarify what you mean by not need a runner and how that influenced the design of TestResult? ... Yes, but isn t setUp
messageBody:
Eric and Vladimir,

> JUnit was designed to not need a runner to execute the tests (and this
> influenced the design with the TestResult). But today everyone uses a
> runner so
> the design of a new framework (SuiteRunner) would most likely be
> different.
>
Could you clarify what you mean by "not need a runner" and how that
influenced the design of TestResult?

>> Test Sequencing
>> ---------------
>>
>> But it's clear that a lot of thought went into JUnit's design.
>> So what is it that makes "sequential tests" undesirable?
>
> if every test share the same resources, you can potentially have some
> very
> tricky problems:
>
> your testA screws up one field of your suite
> testB.... testY run perfectly
> testZ fails
>
> it can be really difficult to discover that testZ was failing because
> of testA.

Yes, but isn't setUp supposed to take care of that kind of problem?
Instead of creating a fixture in the constructor and reusing it in each
test method -- hoping that testA doesn't screw up the fixture in a way
that causes testZ to fail -- you just recreate the fixture anew before
each test method.

All I can see you are buying by creating a new instance for each test
method invocation is that if people screw up their setUp method, it
still doesn't matter. Is there something else I haven't seen?
